abstract: Google refuses to put a link to its privacy policy on its home page, challenging the standards of an advertising industry self-regulatory group it wants to join.
snippet: Google refuses to put a link to its privacy policy on its home page, challenging the standards of an advertising industry self-regulatory group it wants to join.
lead_paragraph: What’s one way that Google is different from AOL, Yahoo and Microsoft? It’s the only one of the big Internet companies that doesn’t put a link to its privacy policy on its home page.

headline.main: Google Fights for the Right to Hide Its Privacy Policy

abstract: Walter Bender left One Laptop Per Child in April and speaks out on Microsoft joining the effort. “Microsoft stepping in is the symptom, not the disease,” he said in the interview. The issue, in his view, is whether the tools that bring computing to children are “agnostic on learning” or “take a position on learning.” Mr. Bender said.
snippet: Walter Bender left One Laptop Per Child in April and speaks out on Microsoft joining the effort. “Microsoft stepping in is the symptom, not the disease,” he said in the interview. The issue, in his view, is whether the tools that bring computing t...
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft joined the One Laptop Per Child project earlier this month, I wrote an article noting the change in heart by both sides. The O.L.P.C. project, intended to bring cheap computers to children in poorer nations, had been committed to using the freely distributed Linux operating system, an open-source alternative to Microsoft’s Windows. And Microsoft had resisted joining anything that promoted open-source software.

headline.main: Why Walter Bender Left One Laptop Per Child
